appendix.title: Achieving PCI-DSS Compliance
appendix.para: If credit or debit card data is processed at your site, it can be necessary to follow the Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard (PCI-DSS). This appendix will help you implement the portions of the standard that relate to the operating system.

note.title: PCI-DSS Is Site-specific
note.para: PCI-DSS implementations vary depending on the site. This guide cannot give a general blueprint.

important.title: PCI-DSS Is Not a Purely Technical Standard
important.para: Large parts of PCI-DSS refer to organizational measures which are not a focus of this document. Always review and follow the original documentation provided at .

important.title: Additional Standards for Software Developers
important.para: If your organisation develops software intended to be PCI-DSS compliant, you could be obliged to additionally follow the PA-DSS standard. This standard is available from .

appendix.para: The first version of PCI-DSS, 1.0, was released in 2004. The current version, 3.0, was released in November 2013 and is valid for the period between January 1, 2014 and December 31, 2016. The PCI-DSS 3.0 specification has the following main requirements:

listitem.para: Build and maintain a secure network and secure systems
Build and maintain a secure network and secure systems

appendix.para: It is important to know that PCI-DSS divides account data into two categories:

listitem.para: Cardholder data which can be stored: Primary Account Number (PAN), cardholder name, expiration date, and the service code.
Sensitive authentication data which must not be stored: magnetic stripe data or equivalent, CAV2/CVC2/CVV2/CID, PIN data.

important.title: When Your Organization Does Not Need to Be PCI-DSS Compliant
important.para:
In many cases, organizations use third-party service providers that handle credit card processing for them. If your organization's equipment comes into contact with cardholder names, expiration dates, and service codes, but not with Primary Account Numbers, there could be no need for your organization to implement PCI-DSS. See also the
PCI-DSS Data Storage Do's and Don'ts .

sect1.title: Securing Networks and Systems
sect1.para: This section of the PCI-DSS standard is concerned with enabling, assessing, and maintaining firewall and router configurations. The second part of this section is concerned with default passwords.

sect2.title: Firewall and Router Configuration
sect2.para: To learn how to set up and maintain a software firewall, see . To correctly set up routers and other network equipment, refer to the documentation of its vendor.

Make sure to run as few services as possible on your computers. Avoid enabling use of protocols and services that are considered insecure, such as IMAP, POP3, or FTP. To regulate inbound and outbound connections, use a whitelist approach.
Protect all computers that could come in contact with account data. Enable a firewall such as &susefirewall; on company or private laptops or other portable computers.

sect2.title: Changing Default Passwords and Other Parameters
sect2.para: Ensure that all passwords used for the operating system are changed from the defaults. In this context, it can be helpful to use a centralized authentication system, such as Kerberos. See also .

procedure.title: Disabling the user wwwrun in &yast;
procedure.para: The user wwwrun is only necessary to run the Apache Web server. Since a computer that stores account data should not need to run a Web server, the user can be disabled.

step.para: Navigate to Security and Users User and Group Management by using the and arrow keys. Open this item by pressing .
Set the filter to System Users by pressing S, S.
Select the entry wwwrun from the list by using the , , and keys.
To disable the account, press until Disable user login appears selected. Activate the check box by pressing . An x will now appear.
Save the setting by pressing O.
To disable more accounts, repeat the previous three steps.
When you are finished, leave the dialog by pressing O and &yast; by pressing Q.
